title: FATAL GUN ACCIDENT KINGSTON MAN SHOT IN STOMACH GUN EXPLODES WHILE LOADING 15 MILES FROM MEDICAL AID The premature explosion of a cartridge, which was being loaded into a pea rifle, is stated to be the cause of a fatal accident which occurred at a week-end camp at Kambah, on the Murrumbidgee River, about 1 p.m., yesterday. title: THE WATER COMES TO GUMLY GUMLY Farmers look forward to bumper crops after long struggle: There is excitement and bustle among the 42 farming families of Gumly Gumly, five miles from Wagga Wagga along the road to Gundagai in southern New South Wales.: After 15 years of patient waiting water has come to Gumly Gumly in lean grey pipes that slide in straight lines like snakes across the dry earth—water for the paddocks, animals, and household needs from the swiftly flowing Murrumbidgee River.

title: SEVERE HEAT WAVE BUSH FIRES OVER WIDE AREA FLAMES SWEEP TOWARDS F.C.T. OVER FRONT EXCEEDING 30 MILES Practically the whole of New South Wales suffered extreme heat yesterday. In Sydney a maximum of 106.2 was recorded. It was still 94 at nine o'clock last night. At Bourke 111 degrees was reached. In Canberra the maximum temperature was 93.2 A huge fire, with a 30-mile front, was 10 miles from the boundary of the Federal Capital Territory early last night, and with a continuance of yesterday's wind will enter the Territory to-day, and reach the Murrumbidgee River between Uriarra and the northern boundary. The meteorologist for New South Wales forecasts better conditions in the southerndistrict, and the south coast, with a southerly wind to-day, but other parts of the State are likely to continue in the throes of the heat-wave.

title: But Breaking, Up of Big Estates Necessary for Success of Scheme In the development of big irrigation schemes on the Murray and Murrumbidgee, marketing difficulties have been encountered which have prejudiced future extensions pending a survey and expansion of markets. On the Lachlan River however, the Wyangala Dam is a great insurance measure against drought. The Wyangala Dam scheme will provide 600 wheat farms covering 800,000 acres, immediately in the Roto-Hillston area, and 226 miles of river frontage will be made irrigable for the growth of lucerne. which the scheme will provide along the river, is deThe extent of the latter and the increased farms pendent on prompt measures being taken by the State Government to break up large estates there.

title: "ROSE OF THE MURRAY" All Rights Reserved.  SYNOPSIS To River's Bend, on the Murray River, came George Jeffrey and his son Gilmore ostensibly to inspect the station property of Mr. Lindsay. After a detailed inspection by his visitors, Lindsay confesses himself beaten. He cannot understand the visitors who had not looked at his sheep but have taken levels, inspected the heights of the river banks and of nearby ridges. When Lindsay's patience is exhausted Jeffrey announces his intention of buying the property. The impatience of Lindsay gives way to blank surprise. He had feared that Jeffrey was spying out the property for gold, but Jeffrey confides his great plans of making the Murray a centre of great productivity as an irrigation area. Little Rose displays great interest in the story. Lindsay tells of how after a big flood on the Murrumbidgee, Darkie found a child two years old on the river and she had been adopted by Miss Lindsay, his sister, who is away on a shoppingexpedition. They had been been unable to establish her identity, but had called her Rose Murray. In order to learn more of Jeffrey's wonderful plans for the river, she asks Jeffrey to accompany her to the river bank, to see some of its pretty spots and where he regales her with stories. She tells him how Darkie told her that she is the daughter of the Great White King who had come along the Murray. Miss Lindsay returns from Goolway with Joe Spark[?]s who is opposed to the Jeffreys scheme on the ground of riparian rights.

title: A Christian Programme for the Murray Valley The diversion of the Snowy River, the estimated 1,700,000 acres feet of water that will be available annually for distribution through the Murray and Murrumbidgee systems, raises a problem for the Christian, said Mr. B. A. Santamaria, National Secretary of the National Catholic Rural Movement, in his address to the large gathering of priests, convened by the N.C.G.M., at "La Verna," Kew, for a three-day conference, an initial report of which appeared in last week's issue. Portion of Mr. Santamaria's lengthy review is here published, omitting mainly technical details and his treatment of the aspects of population, closer settlement, co-operatives and education.
